conclusion: Determine if the car and the truck will collide by analyzing their relative motion using v-t graphs.
Initial conditions: Car's speed is 30 m/s, truck's speed is 10 m/s, and initial distance is 30 m.
Car's velocity decreases linearly from 30 m/s to 10 m/s over 5 seconds; truck's velocity remains constant at 10 m/s.
Calculate car's position over time using uniformly accelerated motion equations.
Car's deceleration is 4 m/s² calculated from the graph.
Car's position as a function of time is x_c(t) = 30 + 30t - 2t².
Calculate truck's position over time with constant speed: x_t(t) = 30 + 10t.
Set car's and truck's positions equal to find when car catches up: 30 + 30t - 2t² = 30 + 10t.
Solve the equation to find t = 0 or t = 10 s.
Check validity: t = 0 is initial time, t = 10 s is when car would catch up if deceleration continued.
Car's speed at t = 10 s is -10 m/s, indicating it has stopped and started moving backward.
Conclusion: Car will not catch up to the truck within the deceleration time frame.
Final answer: The car and the truck will not collide.
